Posts.Title: Playing the waiting game

Posts.Content: I had the same question last year. Prior to starting RT, I had a prepaid trip planned. After discussing this with my RO, I didn’t do the trip. In fact, my treatment went over the Thanksgiving holiday. To compensate for this day off, they had all of us who were going through radiation come in on SUNDAY. I’ve read different ideas on this, but it was very clear to me that my doctor did not want to break my treatment into pieces. You can read about fractionation of treatments, but he wasn’t supportive of that idea.

Posts.Title: Journey update

Posts.Content: I am impressed that there is obvious coordination of care afoot for your dad. Having the urologist and cardiologist talking to each other about both his heart and his prostate is a good sign. And, it sounds as if the priority for care weighs on the side of his heart first and his prostate second. As others have suggested, it would be a very good thing if the urologist (and a urologic oncologist) sat down with the cardiologist and reviewed specifics. As already pointed out, there are clear options besides surgery (Gleason 7 notwithstanding), and having a second opinion and a multidisciplinary team of doctors communicating, I think this is a good plan of attack!

Posts.Title: Should we delay the surgery?

Posts.Content: I'll put the stats down in the profile section after this post, but since this is my first, I'll put it in the text. FIRST. Thanks to all of you for what I've learned about PCa from this forum. Age: 72. Have had rising and falling PSA since 2012. Tested twice a year for 5 years. PSA of 9.8 on 12/16. DRE's every time I got PSA results, always negative. After having the "sword of Damocles" hanging over my head for all these years, I asked for a biopsy. 12 cores done on 1/4. Four cores were 3 + 3, six cores were 3+ 4, two cores were 4 +3 (right base less than 5% involved, right mid 60% involved. Not happy about this, but not surprised either. Began educating myself about PCa when I started the semi-annual PSA drill, but it's now more than academic. Have followed the Hopkins newsletter as well as MSK data. Didn't find this site until last week, and now have another resource and lots of great insights from veterans and new guys (like me). The urological practice I've been going to has an outstanding reputation and is extremely well-run. My urologist diagnosed interstitial cystitis back in 1988 after the best docs at Walter Reed (I was a career Army guy), couldn't figure out why I had hematuria and bladder pain. I met with the surgeon last week. Discussed pathology. I asked about sending biopsy to Dr. Epstein at Hopkins for review. (He was surprised I knew who he was.) He said, "of course we can do that, but I should tell you that the pathologist who did your report worked for Epstein at Hopkins and has a terrific reputation." Hmmmm. That base sounds covered. So, at 72 the conversation turns to best option. Fortunately, I have zero health concerns -- no heart, lung, kidney, diabetes, etc. And, I am in great physical condition. Not overweight, have worked out 2-3x weekly with a personal trainer for the past two years, etc. So, we discussed radiotherapy or a robotic. (I had done both a CT and bone scan the week prior -- both negative.) Plan to do the Robotic, and surgeon believes I will have minimal issues. As you get "chronologically gifted" recovery (especially incontinence) can be tougher, but I"m an optimist. My check on the surgeon: top grades from other patients/doctors, was early in the DaVinci game, has mentored others in the robotic prostatectomy business, has done more than 1,000. Will do a consult before I make final call as to where to have this done. At this stage I'm optimistic about outcomes -- though I don't have rose colored glasses when it comes to cancer --- my dad died of colon cancer at 61, my brother died of a glioblastoma multiform at 62, my mom of ovarian at 83 -- oh, and I lost my wife to brain cancer (Astrocytoma grade III) when she was 46. BUT, she was diagnosed at age 32 and lived 13 years. Cancer has been a part of my life for a long time. Now I get to deal with it up close and VERY personally. But, I'm ready to take it on!

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Barry: You've got this fully UC! (Under Control). Congrats! Getting the MRI prior to surgery indicates a highly diligent surgeon. This will allow detection (90%) and assessment of your PC status and identify any looming surprises in advance. We're with you every step of the way. Good luck! MF I've had two appointments with the physical therapy staff. While my personal trainer works on strength training, these two folks put my through some rigorous training and exercise on pelvic floor strengthening. The last appointment including placing leads around my anal area and then measuring my ability to "flex" and strengthen my musculature to improve continency. I could see this on the computer screen. Pretty fascinating and an exercise I'd never though of. I have one more session prior to surgery, then follow-up 30 days post prostatectomy. Also saw the results of the Multidetector CT imaging they did a few weeks ago. Findings: Prostate: 50 mm in diameter No gross estracapsular extension Seminal vessels grossly normal Bladder normal No pelvic lymphadenopathy No aggressive osseous lesion in pelvis Next week is the MRI with the endorectal coil as well as preop work. I'm really ready to get this to the next stage. AND, I'm hoping to NOT need the big box of incontinent pads that arrived yesterday. Thanks to all of you who've posted stuff to help me get ready for this. I can't tell you how encouraging its been to see not only the results, but the fantastic attitude of guys who've been through this drill and are getting on with life! Barry

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the positive vibrations, and very cogent and useful suggestions. There is nothing of greater value than having input from others who have (and are) experiencing cancer. I most definitely learned this when dealing with my wife's 13 years of dealing with it. (I became very proficient in dealing with neurologists, hematology-oncologists, CT scans, MRI's. BUT, it is different this time.) My post-military field has been behavioral science and I've spent about 30 years working with people to improve their ability to lead others--mostly by understanding themselves first. I know my strengths and weaknesses and how I process information and make decisions. My decision style is to amass significant amounts of data, examine it, ask, "so what am I missing?" and make a call. This has a downside to it if you don't ask that last question. The posts you guys have made confirmed a lot of my thoughts and also helped me uncover areas I hadn't adequately addressed. So, I've done some more work, and have a plan of action. (In the Army, this would be called an Operations Order -- commonly known as an OpOrd!) After a bit more investigation, I have confirmed that the surgeon is seen as outstanding, experienced, and thorough by other patients, and he gets a great review from my regular doc, whom I've been seeing since 1988. As noted by several of you, the 4 + 3 puts me in the intermediate phase, so active surveillance entails more risk than I'd be willing to take. We discussed the radiology option -- which is entirely feasible. Given the totality of what I'm looking at, I think (for me), the prostatectomy is the way to go. He has scheduled me for an MRI so he can get a complete picture of what he can expect -- particular the approach he wants to take. We will go for nerve sparing on both sides, but he will make the call when he's got a better picture. The MRI will help with this. I'm also being scheduled for sessions with their physical therapist to begin strengthening the pelvic floor well before the surgery. Current plan is to get this scheduled in mid-March. Since I had the biopsy in January, things should be well healed. (I had zero issues with infection, bleeding, etc. from the biopsy...I was actually surprised that this was only moderately uncomfortable.) I was even prepared for really gross semen. I was not disappointed, but that's all fine now. I've read the Walsh book (3d edition) and found it really helpful. There were sections that I did a light skim on -- particularly some of the more exotic therapy. Hopefully, I won't get to that point. It means a lot to have you guys as fellow journeymen. I lurked on this site for several months before I had the biopsy. There was no doubt in my mind that I would someday face a challenge like this. It's very helpful to have guys like Chuck, Michael, Brandon -- well all of you as "unpaid consultants" to help me beat this. I'd also say that my life has been so filled with family members who fought the cancer battle before me. I have plenty of role models to emulate. Best to all of you! Barry

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the positive vibrations, and very cogent and useful suggestions. There is nothing of greater value than having input from others who have (and are) experiencing cancer. I most definitely learned this when dealing with my wife's 13 years of dealing with it. (I became very proficient in dealing with neurologists, hematology-oncologists, CT scans, MRI's. BUT, it is different this time.) My post-military field has been behavioral science and I've spent about 30 years working with people to improve their ability to lead others--mostly by understanding themselves first. I know my strengths and weaknesses and how I process information and make decisions. My decision style is to amass significant amounts of data, examine it, ask, "so what am I missing?" and make a call. This has a downside to it if you don't ask that last question. The posts you guys have made confirmed a lot of my thoughts and also helped me uncover areas I hadn't adequately addressed. So, I've done some more work, and have a plan of action. (In the Army, this would be called an Operations Order -- commonly known as an OpOrd!) After a bit more investigation, I have confirmed that the surgeon is seen as outstanding, experienced, and thorough by other patients, and he gets a great review from my regular doc, whom I've been seeing since 1988. As noted by several of you, the 4 + 3 puts me in the intermediate phase, so active surveillance entails more risk than I'd be willing to take. We discussed the radiology option -- which is entirely feasible. Given the totality of what I'm looking at, I think (for me), the prostatectomy is the way to go. He has scheduled me for an MRI so he can get a complete picture of what he can expect -- particular the approach he wants to take. We will go for nerve sparing on both sides, but he will make the call when he's got a better picture. The MRI will help with this. I'm also being scheduled for sessions with their physical therapist to begin strengthening the pelvic floor well before the surgery. Current plan is to get this scheduled in mid-March. Since I had the biopsy in January, things should be well healed. (I had zero issues with infection, bleeding, etc. from the biopsy...I was actually surprised that this was only moderately uncomfortable.) I was even prepared for really gross semen. I was not disappointed, but that's all fine now. I've read the Walsh book (3d edition) and found it really helpful. There were sections that I did a light skim on -- particularly some of the more exotic therapy. Hopefully, I won't get to that point. It means a lot to have you guys as fellow journeymen. I lurked on this site for several months before I had the biopsy. There was no doubt in my mind that I would someday face a challenge like this. It's very helpful to have guys like Chuck, Michael, Brandon -- well all of you as "unpaid consultants" to help me beat this. I'd also say that my life has been so filled with family members who fought the cancer battle before me. I have plenty of role models to emulate. Best to all of you! Barry
Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: I'll put the stats down in the profile section after this post, but since this is my first, I'll put it in the text. FIRST. Thanks to all of you for what I've learned about PCa from this forum. Age: 72. Have had rising and falling PSA since 2012. Tested twice a year for 5 years. PSA of 9.8 on 12/16. DRE's every time I got PSA results, always negative. After having the "sword of Damocles" hanging over my head for all these years, I asked for a biopsy. 12 cores done on 1/4. Four cores were 3 + 3, six cores were 3+ 4, two cores were 4 +3 (right base less than 5% involved, right mid 60% involved. Not happy about this, but not surprised either. Began educating myself about PCa when I started the semi-annual PSA drill, but it's now more than academic. Have followed the Hopkins newsletter as well as MSK data. Didn't find this site until last week, and now have another resource and lots of great insights from veterans and new guys (like me). The urological practice I've been going to has an outstanding reputation and is extremely well-run. My urologist diagnosed interstitial cystitis back in 1988 after the best docs at Walter Reed (I was a career Army guy), couldn't figure out why I had hematuria and bladder pain. I met with the surgeon last week. Discussed pathology. I asked about sending biopsy to Dr. Epstein at Hopkins for review. (He was surprised I knew who he was.) He said, "of course we can do that, but I should tell you that the pathologist who did your report worked for Epstein at Hopkins and has a terrific reputation." Hmmmm. That base sounds covered. So, at 72 the conversation turns to best option. Fortunately, I have zero health concerns -- no heart, lung, kidney, diabetes, etc. And, I am in great physical condition. Not overweight, have worked out 2-3x weekly with a personal trainer for the past two years, etc. So, we discussed radiotherapy or a robotic. (I had done both a CT and bone scan the week prior -- both negative.) Plan to do the Robotic, and surgeon believes I will have minimal issues. As you get "chronologically gifted" recovery (especially incontinence) can be tougher, but I"m an optimist. My check on the surgeon: top grades from other patients/doctors, was early in the DaVinci game, has mentored others in the robotic prostatectomy business, has done more than 1,000. Will do a consult before I make final call as to where to have this done. At this stage I'm optimistic about outcomes -- though I don't have rose colored glasses when it comes to cancer --- my dad died of colon cancer at 61, my brother died of a glioblastoma multiform at 62, my mom of ovarian at 83 -- oh, and I lost my wife to brain cancer (Astrocytoma grade III) when she was 46. BUT, she was diagnosed at age 32 and lived 13 years. Cancer has been a part of my life for a long time. Now I get to deal with it up close and VERY personally. But, I'm ready to take it on!

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Barry: You've got this fully UC! (Under Control). Congrats! Getting the MRI prior to surgery indicates a highly diligent surgeon. This will allow detection (90%) and assessment of your PC status and identify any looming surprises in advance. We're with you every step of the way. Good luck! MF I've had two appointments with the physical therapy staff. While my personal trainer works on strength training, these two folks put my through some rigorous training and exercise on pelvic floor strengthening. The last appointment including placing leads around my anal area and then measuring my ability to "flex" and strengthen my musculature to improve continency. I could see this on the computer screen. Pretty fascinating and an exercise I'd never though of. I have one more session prior to surgery, then follow-up 30 days post prostatectomy. Also saw the results of the Multidetector CT imaging they did a few weeks ago. Findings: Prostate: 50 mm in diameter No gross estracapsular extension Seminal vessels grossly normal Bladder normal No pelvic lymphadenopathy No aggressive osseous lesion in pelvis Next week is the MRI with the endorectal coil as well as preop work. I'm really ready to get this to the next stage. AND, I'm hoping to NOT need the big box of incontinent pads that arrived yesterday. Thanks to all of you who've posted stuff to help me get ready for this. I can't tell you how encouraging its been to see not only the results, but the fantastic attitude of guys who've been through this drill and are getting on with life! Barry

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: Just to refresh, I was diagnosed back in March after RALP and diagnosis/pathology report: pT3aN1; PSA post surgery was .2 Did a consult at Johns Hopkins after surgery in Greensboro, enrolled in a clinical trial at Johns Hopkins on 17 May 17, Phase II study of definitive therapy for newly diagnosed men with oligometastatic prostate cancer after prostatectomy" 1. Docetaxel, 4 sessions at 3 week interval. Initiated 15 Jun 17; completed 15 Sep 17 2. Initiate ADT (Lupron) at first chemo session, repeat quarterly 3. Radiation therapy; 38 treatments, completed 28 4. 15 Sep PSA was .1 At initial consult, tested for genetic issues. At second meeting, doctor notified me that I had dMMR (mismatch repair deficiency). This is a genetic condition that in essence means you have screwed up DNA. Historically it shows up with predilection for colon cancer (my Dad died of this at age 61), brain cancer (my brother died of a glioblastoma at age 62), and some other hereditary nastiness. On 23 May 2017, the FDA approved the use of Pembrolizumab (Keytruda) if a patient has dMMR and who have not had satisfactory alternative treatment options. The news release also stated, Until now, the FDA has approved cancer treatments based on where in the body the cancer started -- for example, lung or breast cancers. We have now approved a drug based on a tumors biomarker without regard to the tumors original location. Keytruda was approved for new indications using the Accelerated Approval pathway, under which the FDA may approve drugs for serious conditions where there is unmet medical need and a drug is shown to have certain effects that are reasonably likely to predict a clinical benefit to patients. I have no clue of the incidence of dMMR (another condition called MSI-H is also included), but for me, if I need to bail out of my clinical trial, my Dr. will put me on the Keytruda. (There are some early studies RE: Keytruda and PCa, but its probably too early to be predictive. Some results have been astounding. After getting the results of this testing I asked, how likely is it that my doctors at home would have given me this test? The answer: not likely I share this in case it may help one of my brothers out there reading this AMAZING forum. Barry

AgeInfo.Phrase: died of this at age 61   brain cancer  my brother died
of a glioblastoma at age 62   and some other hereditary nastiness

Posts.Title: Mismatch Repair Deficiency (dMMR) and Keytruda for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: To Michael’s question: yes, I will complete radiation therapy and all the other codicils of the clinical trial (ADT, a lot of measurement, testing, etc.). The idea of moving to Keytruda would be if the usual therapies are ineffective. I could, obviously opt out of the trial and go to Keytruda -- and we discussed that option. As long as I continue to do well, it seems to make sense to only to to the Keytruda if deemed medically necessary. To Fairwind's question on cost: I retired from the military and my TriCare will cover the cost of the drug. Thus far, TriCare has covered everything that Medicare hasn't. For anyone reading this who’s in the 1% of our population currently serving their country, there are some long term benefits for giving 20 or more years of your life to your Country. Oh, the approximate annual cost for Keytruda therapy is $160,000. Merck will undoubtedly recover their discovery and NDA costs as more and more physicians find that Keytruda can (and is) doing amazing things in treating Cancer. My doctor at Hopkins is Clinical Director of Research for Prostate Cancer, Dr. Kenneth Pienta. I cannot say enough good things about this gifted scientist. At the end of our first meeting, I stood to shake his hand and he said, “wouldn’t your rather have an anti-cancer hug?” He also said, “while I could ‘treat’ your Cancer, I am much more interested in KILLING it.” Just an amazing guy....and the same adjective applies to Jane and Donnie. If I send an email at weird hours I get responses from them at equally weird hours. I’ve had a lot of experience in major medical centers, but I’ve never felt the warmth and caring that I’ve experienced from every single person at Johns Hopkins.

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: There are some similarities in your stats and mine. As you’ll also see, I’m in a clinical trial at Johns Hopkins. This is post RALP which was done in Greensboro (I see you had treatment in Durham). The trial started with Docetaxel (4 treatments over around 12 weeks), also started ADT coincident with first chemo. You can see the scope of the radiation treatment in the stats. My protocol includes quarterly ADT, PSA, Testosterone Level and usual CBC. Doctor at Hopkins very pleased with response to treatment thus far, as PSA is (his words) “undetectable.” Trial is for two years, though Dr. says he’ll be following me for the rest of my life (which I hope is a long one!) There seems to be a constant stream of research updates on metastatic PC. A good thing.

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: Having been part of the slay the beast! for two years is a head shaker. The time has moved so quickly. Were it not for the serial side effects of the ADT, I have had few reminders that I had this disease. Since my work puts me in front of groups, I talk to each group about PC. Often Ill commiserate with women of a certain age that I truly understand the ugliness of hot flashes. I couple of weeks ago I had a lady who was fanning herself at a front table. I said,how about fanning up here as well. The entire class laughed and applauded. I cant tell you how many men and women come up to me to talk about a PSA. Lastly, I think you guys ....you long timers....provide such amazing support and information that I find it hard to not get emotional (I get Lupron tomorrow!). When I remember the terror of my diagnosis and what those first weeks felt like; well all of us have that in common. I have an awesome medical team and a wonderful family supporting me. I also have you guys. So, at the two year mark I just want to say thanks to each of you for the wonderful, and very kind words of support.The camaraderie that flows across our valiant band of brothers is very real, and its surely helped me get through biopsy, surgery, chemo, radiation, and (yes), even 2 years of ADT.
Posts.Title: Darolutamide Looking Good

Posts.Content: This treatment looks really promising for those of us with MCRPC. Low toxicity and a 22 month add on to progression is most surely significant. Making it through Phase 3 with such positive results is todays good news. Check it out: https://prostatecancernewstoday.com/...aign=OneSignal

Posts.Title: Darolutamide Looking Good

Posts.Content: Michael, I head to Hopkins tomorrow for a Monday appointment The appointment is the contracted 2 year end of the Phase 2 study Ive been a part of. I do have to have a one and body scan plus CBC, Testisterone, PSA, and Metabolic Panel. Several months back, I asked Dr Pienta how long he expected to follow me. His answer was very direct: For the rest of your life. My treatment protocol was designed for a curative outcome. I had a pretty heavy burden of stuff going on, but he has been very optimistic throughout the 2 years. Well see.
Posts.Title: Darolutamide Looking Good

Posts.Content: I can really understand where you are. Getting to the facts seems to make time go more slowly. As I’m sure you’ve read elsewhere (Pat Walsh’s book, for sure), you really do have time with PCa to go through a process that can be loaded with facts that load into the best possible diagnosis. Once you and your medical team are comfortable with that, you can move to whatever makes the most sense. You really do have time to do this -- if it is PCa, it’s one of slowest growing cancers. And, then you have time for an optimum treatment plan -- that’ll have good science in it rather than emotion. Hang in there!

Posts.Title: Diagnosis question

Posts.Content: I’ve been on ADT for 9 months. Maybe I should ask others if they’ve seen any diminution in my cognitive ability? Anyway, I consult in the field of executive leadership. I kept all of my commitments since I began this ADT process, and through careful scheduling, I worked up to the beginning of EBRT. Schedule-wise, I restarted after I’d had 69 Gy of radiation. If I had gotten sloppy in ideation, they would have told me. I also have 9 consulting sessions ahead of me. YMMV.

Posts.Title: Impact of ADT on Self-reported Cognitive Function in Men with PCa

Posts.Content: Some of the decision making process is due to our psychological wiring. There are those who only make decisions after assembling as much data as possible, then moving on. Others are prone to make a call based on what “feels” right, or what their intuition tells them. Is there anything more intensely personal than making a tough call on what to do after a cancer diagnosis? There’s a natural tendency to defend a decision already made. What I have valued most about this forum has been the wide range of “how I decided to do what I did.” This proved invaluable to me 14 months ago when I was trying to make a call for myself. My life history just couldn’t push me in the direction of communicating (or on-communicating!) with someone who forbade honest discussion of alternatives. It almost seems a bit like invoking the “thought police” which surely hampers an open and honest conversation.

Posts.Title: One Year Post Op

Posts.Content: I had a colonoscopy just prior to IMRT (my Dad died of colon cancer). I’ve been religious about a 5 year check for about 15 years. I’d had polyps in each of the last three. None in my last check -- good news. My RT consisted of a total of 69 Gy. 46 to the pelvic fossa and 23 boost. I finished in late November ’17. SO FAR, I haven’t had any serious issues, though I definitely have a different elimination schedule. It seems as if I’ll go a couple of days, then have a massive set of clean outs and repeat the process. I’ve been told that there can be long term complications from the IMRT, and that they can occur (sometimes) years post therapy. Just one more thing to pay attention to, right?

Posts.Title: More 'good' news, Radiation Colitis

Posts.Content: Mintlatte, if it’s any comfort, I too was diagnosed with Stage IV metastatic PC. While I didn’t have as high a PSA, or some of the complications you mention, I did go through the same chemo treatment your husband is taking and I’m also on ADT. If it’s any comfort to you, the chemo and ADT brought my PSA score to .1. While getting a cure would be wonderful, this disease is eminently treatable. I look at a bit like going into a maze. You come to one dead end and turn left. Here’s treatment for that. Then you walk a bit further and there’s another dead end. Turn right. There’s another treatment available. While your husband is younger than most of us, that is probably a positive for him. Let us know what happens. We’re all pulling for you both.

Posts.Title: 46 YO - Stage IV with no symptoms?

Posts.Content: Many of us on this Forum can truly understand the enormous impact a PCa diagnosis has on not just those of us who have it, but also our family members. The suggestions you’re receiving are based on our own personal experiences, and his (and yours) may differ. BUT, the best weapon for either treatment (or cure -- though that sounds less likely from the info you’ve been given) is KNOWLEDGE. From my experience, putting my trust in an expert created an environment for me that was grounded in top notch medical care. I went from my home in Greensboro, NC to Baltimore, MD to get that expertise at Johns Hopkins. For sure you want to have an appointment for him at the Cleveland Clinic as soon as you can get one. THEN you’ll have a much clearer idea of treatment options. Trust me, he does have treatment options. Finally, and perhaps this is just me -- as I coped with a very scary pathology -- I decided that IF this nasty disease is going to put me down, I wanted to be able to say to my son that I did everything I possibly could to beat the disease. I don’t believe I could have said that if I didn’t seek out the very best treatment options. He lost his Mom to brain cancer when he was 18 (he’s now 42), and I want to be a Dad and Grandad as long as I can. He probably feels much the same, and your seeking out this forum tells me a lot about how you love him. There is treatment for him that will make a difference. I’m sure you’ve read many of the options here on cancerforums.net. Good luck!

AgeInfo.Phrase: he was 18  he’s now 42   and I want to be

Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: My doctor at Hopkins is director of clinical research for prostate cancer. He gave me genetic tests at my first appointment. “I really like to know what I’m dealing with, and if there’s something out there that we could be facing besides PC.” Results: negative for about 15 kinds of genetically related cancers; my PC is “environmental.” He did find that I have something called a “mismatch repair deficiency.” (An inherited difficulty in killing off cancer cells.) Having this information makes me eligible for Keytruda if other therapies don’t work, as the FDA approved this drug for MMdR. From what you’ve described, your treatment plan is VERY close to mine, including the RT. I had 69 Gy, 46 to the bed and 23 boost to those areas where there was activity (a couple of lymph nodes, prostate bed). As far as the chemo is concerned, here’s what my JH doctor said. “We know there is some systemic activity as it was in a couple of lymph nodes, so the chemo is designed to kill that off.” I started ADT at the same time as the chemo as his research indicates that the ADT tends to sensitize the PC cells. I had a gap of about 6 weeks from the time I completed chemo until I started the RT. My clinical trial includes quarterly check-ups as well as bone/body scans. I’ve had two; both negative. Last 4 PSA’s have been 0.1. Let me know if there’s anything I can do to shed more light on what my treatment plan includes. Barry

Posts.Title: Started Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Keep good spirits! I started a clinical trial (post RALP) at Johns Hopkins for guys with metastatic PCa. The regiment started off with 4 sessions of Docetaxel (each session separated by 3 weeks). Also began Lupron on same day as starting chemo. My major side effect from the chemo was tiredness -- which began on day 5 after chemo and lasted about 4 days. My hair thinned but I did NOT lose it. After completing chemo I had 69 Gray of radiation. PSA has been tested each quarter after surgery and has stayed at .01. Have been reading a LOT of research (as most of us do!), and it seems as if administering docetaxel for guys like us has become popular. My doc (Dr. Pienta) feels that administering the chemo early treats some of the systemic cells (I had two lymph nodes that tested positive.) Not enjoying the ADT, but you do what you gotta do!

Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Mintlatte, if it’s any comfort, I too was diagnosed with Stage IV metastatic PC. While I didn’t have as high a PSA, or some of the complications you mention, I did go through the same chemo treatment your husband is taking and I’m also on ADT. If it’s any comfort to you, the chemo and ADT brought my PSA score to .1. While getting a cure would be wonderful, this disease is eminently treatable. I look at a bit like going into a maze. You come to one dead end and turn left. Here’s treatment for that. Then you walk a bit further and there’s another dead end. Turn right. There’s another treatment available. While your husband is younger than most of us, that is probably a positive for him. Let us know what happens. We’re all pulling for you both.

Posts.Title: 46 YO - Stage IV with no symptoms?

Posts.Content: Keep good spirits! I started a clinical trial (post RALP) at Johns Hopkins for guys with metastatic PCa. The regiment started off with 4 sessions of Docetaxel (each session separated by 3 weeks). Also began Lupron on same day as starting chemo. My major side effect from the chemo was tiredness -- which began on day 5 after chemo and lasted about 4 days. My hair thinned but I did NOT lose it. After completing chemo I had 69 Gray of radiation. PSA has been tested each quarter after surgery and has stayed at .01. Have been reading a LOT of research (as most of us do!), and it seems as if administering docetaxel for guys like us has become popular. My doc (Dr. Pienta) feels that administering the chemo early treats some of the systemic cells (I had two lymph nodes that tested positive.) Not enjoying the ADT, but you do what you gotta do!

Posts.Title: BONE and CAT Scan - what to except

Posts.Content: My partner is 62 and was having what sounded like BPH last June. He scheduled an appointment with our family practice doc. Was seen by the PA. PA did DRE, found a pea size nodule and prescribed a course of CIPRO. Did PSA. PSA came back as 4.54. Referred to Urologist in Aug 18. Uro ordered PSA and did DRE, noted pea size nodule. PSA came back as 2.1. Scheduled for follow up Jan ’19. At Jan appointment, Uro did DRE, said the lump was the size of a marble and ran PSA. PSA came back as 2.6. Uro ordered MRI, refused by Insurance. Uro wants to run biopsy (“out of abundance of caution”) Insurance refused to pay for biopsy with a 2.6 PSA. My slightly educated impression would say: “slow stream, let’s try a course of antibiotics and do PSA to be on safe side. Return after course of Cipro, PSA drops to 2.1. “Aha! we have cleared the infection, (but let’s check again to be safe)". Recheck in 5 months, PSA is 2.6. Has anyone some insight into doing a prostatic biopsy with a PSA that bumped .5 in 5 months and a nodule that seems to be growing? Is it unusual to order a biopsy with a 2.6 PSA? What’s the likelihood a nodule would influence PSA score? Ideas would really be welcome. (The stats below are MINE. Please just comment on what’s above.)

Posts.Title: PSA of 2.6 and Uro wants to do a PSA. Comments?

Posts.Content: Next Monday I get my last Lupron injection. This marks 2 full years on ADT. It HAS been a slog, but even with G9, my PSA has remained undetectable. The side effects youve read about? Ive had almost all of them to one degree or another. But before I sound like a whiner: My Doc carefully explained at my first appointment that his goal was to kill my cancer rather than treat it. The ADT was to sensitize my system so that the chemo therapy would be enhanced. After completing chemo, the continuing ADT would further improve my response to the 69 Gy of radiation. I agree about the importance of exercising. Ive worked out with a trainer for 6 years. The bi-weekly workouts while on Lupron have been much tougher. More adipose tissue, shortness of breath, hot flashes, all of the SE that Id read about came to pass. I wouldnt change a thing. Theres nothing I cant do that I could have done prior to ADT. BUT, almost every physical activity has been much tougher. The shortness of breath has....by far....been the most crushing side effect. There were times in my workouts when my trainer would make me sit down to catch my breath. Hated that. Lastly, my libido has completely disappeared. While I definitely miss it, the mere fact that Ive enjoyed the last 2 years anyway...well it could be a whole lot worse.
Posts.Title: Second 6 month Lupron Injection

Posts.Content: Had my quarterly blood letting (CBC, Metabolic Panel, Testosterone, PSA) at Hopkins on Monday. Some of the CBC and Metabolic panel results were weird. Explanation. Completing two full years of ADT has had its impact on everything from red cells to glucose levels. BUT, I had my last Eligard injection. Doctor said that we’d start seeing some testosterone kick in by mid to late summer. Any testosterone would be better than under 20! PSA results arrived today. I continue my membership along with the rest of the “undetectables.” A group to which I am happy to be a part of! Dr. Pienta feels I have a better than even shot at curing this awful G9 prostate cancer. That sounds really good and makes the past two years on ADT worthwhile. ADT plus chemo, then ADT plus radiation has been a slog. (The only thing I haven’t had with ADT has been a gin and tonic.) If the research shows that ADT sensitizes the cancer cells making chemo and radiation more potent -- well, we’ll have quite a few months (hopefully, years), to check the outcome. Thanks to all of you guys for helping me stay positive. I dedicate a past hot-flash to each and every one of you!

Posts.Title: Still a Club Member

Posts.Content: I live in Greensboro, NC. I had biopsy and RALP in Greensboro. Once the post-surgery pathology report kicked in, I transferred follow-up care to the Brady Urological Institute at Johns Hopkins. As you can see in my signature, it turned out to be very serious cancer (G-9), lymph node involvement, etc. I’ve been in a clinical trial at Hopkins since June 2017. In order to be compliant to the trial, I go to Hopkins for 1 day a month. I have had three appointments back-to-back. Blood draw for CBC, Metabolic Panel, Testosterone and PSA. I’ve had an injection (either Lupron , Trelstar, or Eligard) every 90 days for two years. Monday was my last injection of Eligard. (Yes, I’m glad it’s over) Hopkins has been amazing as has been my local cancer center (Wesley Long). I had 70 Gy of radiation in Greensboro, and a couple of times Hopkins let me off the quarterly appointment and allowed me do bloodworm and ADT injection in Greensboro. I WAS very concerned about coordinating care. I failed to realize that this is quite normal. Both sites are on “Epic” so it is not an issue to see what’s going on at Hopkins or in Greensboro. My radiology/oncologist drew up the radiation plan, sent it to Hopkins, then took the time to call my Hopkins doc to make sure he approved the plan. Initially I made quite a few trips to Baltimore, mainly because I had four sessions of Docetaxel, and JH felt I should to the chemo at their place. There is a lot of blood drawn post chemo and pre chemo. I became good friends with the phlebotomist at the local LabCorp facility. Each does of chemo required 3 different blood draws. (That was a total of 12 vials of blood.) Hopkins could not do chemo without very fresh CBC results. If they didn’t have the sample they needed, I’d have missed a chemo treatment. I think sharing the responsibility for treatment is a bit more complicated. Is it worth it? If you see where I started this journey and where I am two years later, you’d agree that this was a smart move. Not to be melodramatic, but I’ve had two years (pretty trouble free), and my Doctor at Hopkins feels I have a real shot at curing my cancer.. When I started the process I decided that I would take complete responsibility for myself. Obviously, I’ve had a lot of support and world class treatment. Everyone is different, everyone has life issues to deal with. I’d like to be dealing with them for many more years. Good luck with whatever you do!

Posts.Title: Integrating distant and local care

Posts.Content: If you’re on the regular PSA circuit (as most of us are), having one in the near future is always on the horizon. I try not to dwell on it. If there’s an “advantage” to PCa it’s that there’s an available metric that highlights good news or bad news without the invasive evaluation of some kind of biopsy. For me, I want to know what I’m dealing with rather than “hoping” something is or isn’t happening. A forthcoming PSA is just another event to deal with. But, it surely is nice when the results are agreeable. Yes, another 90 days is something for which to be thankful!

Posts.Content: One year now post RALP and the awful pathology report -- metastatic PCa, Gleason 9, etc. First PSA post surgery (May 2017) was 0.2. Began clinical trial at Hopkins in June 2017, chemo, radiation, ADT therapy. 3 more PSAs since the 0.2. All three were 0.1. Had my Annual Wellness Exam today with my PCP. ANOTHER PSA, but today (drumroll) 0.00 Im obviously very happy about this turn of events, but I also know theres more stuff ahead of me. For those of you who get the really bad pathology report post surgery....truly there is hope for you too!

Posts.Title: Pretty Amazed

Posts.Content: Good news! Biopsy came back negative. We know that the biopsy process isn’t 100% sure of everything, but at least one of us doesn’t have to join the PCa club right now. The biopsy occurred on Friday. The results came back on Monday. Mine took 6 days. Guess the specimen(s) got to the lab on a slow day. I forgot to mention that he’s 62. I was 72 at age of diagnosis. Will put that in my signature...

Posts.Title: Pretty Amazed

Posts.Content: My partner has been by my side through all the stages of PC. From biospsy, diagnosis, treatment planning, RALP, incontinence, chemo, Radiation, hot flashes, you get the idea. His urologist saw an increasing number with a tad more volume change as well. He had his 12 core biopsy today. The next week will be murder waiting for path reports. Im really hoping for nothing more than 3-3. Only one of us with this disease is fair. Two would constitute cruel and unusual punished. He goat a lot of coaching. A bit of blood is about it.

Posts.Title: Two in one Household With PC?

Posts.Content: I completed my two year clinical trial today through administration of a CT scan of my my abdomen and pelvis. I had two doses of contrast, one each hour at two hour and one hour Intervals prior to the scan. Also, more contrast through an IV just prior to the initial clunk of the scanner itself. I have some old age going on. A bulging disc at L3/L4. A few kidney stones to look forward to. Some arteries that show more steak and burgers than oily fish and raw vegetables. What I do NOT have is any evidence whatsoever of metastatic prostate disease. No other organ involvement and no bone mets. Totally clean. Going into this a couple of years ago I can admit to being terrified with the pathology I was dealing with. There are quite a few of you who were of major help in moving me from fear to action. Thank you! I can only conclude that the clinical trial I signed up for at Johns Hopkins has arrested further metastatic activity. Over two years of undetectable PSAs, along with todays CT scan leave me with the impression that we have stopped the G9 cancer as well as any visible systemic bad behavior from the affected lymph nodes. The ADT is also over. Im much more optimistic of avoiding BCR, but Im going to be followed at Hopkins on a quarterly basis for who knows how long. If it does come back, there are plenty of other arrows in the treatment quiver! Brothers who have a serious case of G9 combined with ugly stuff like EPE, positive margins, positive lymph nodes. etc., stay strong. My treatment plan has provided me with two years of freedom from further cancer activity, and while it is obviously much too early to shout CURE, it is not too early to conclude that Dr. Pienta has at least one subject who has completed Phase 2 of his clinical trial: RALP + ADT + Chemo + EBRT + prayer + loving family and friends = yours truly.

Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: My doctor at Hopkins did genetic tests as I joined a clinical trial last year (post RALP). He found that I have mismatch repair syndrome. The FDA approved use of Keytruda for anyone with this condition without regard for tumor type or tumor location. The approval was granted in May 2017. If the treatment Ive been given fails, there may be a point where I would go to Keytruda for my metastatic PC.

Posts.Title: Gleason 10 prostate cancer and still fighting with Keytruda

Posts.Content: Hi Trex, In looking at your stats, it looks like you have a mixed bag to deal with. All of us go through the anguish of PSA results. For whatever, reason, my Doctor at Hopkins is more comfortable without the ultra sensitive version. I asked him about it 18 months ago and he said that we’d get what we needed from the standard version. I’m guessing this may be a “urologist’s choice” kind of thing. I’ve had two PSA’s in the last 10 days. One for an annual physical (0.1), and then a second was done locally and sent to Hopkins to close out the clinical trial. It, too was 0.1. So in the past 4 weeks I’ve had three PSA’s. The were evaluated by three different labs and they were all 0.1

Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: I would also have been disturbed at the lack of conversation on the effect of ADT. I can tell you from personal experience that 2 weeks after my first injection of Trelstar, my equipment shut down. After two months I lost complete and total interest in sex. This was really disturbing, because I got interested in my early teens and never got disinterested. Ive been on Trelstar, Eligard, and Lupron. They are all the same in terms of side effects. I have been on this regimen now for two years. As of my last testosterone value (this was on 2 April), it was under 3. The normal male is somewhere between 264-916 (according to LabCorp). OTOH, without sounding like a negaholic, my PSA has been 0.1 for almost two years. THAT makes it worth it! There is research that shows if you are on ADT (a must for my situation), it heightens the effect of the radiation therapy. It also increases the PCas sensitivity to chemo. You can read all about this in Walshs book (and Im sure you have) none of this will come as a surprise. There are just lots of tradeoffs in both going for a cure, and in the treatment modality. I had my last and final ADT injection on 11 March. Ill know more by mid-summer when my testosterone begins to reactivate. I surely wont miss the weight gain, hot flashes, and the feminization of my body. Guess Id have to say -- taking the long view -- it was the right therapy for what Im dealing with. Everyone is different, and I think thats worth paying attention to! They told me Id lose my hair undergoing chemo. I didnt. Some of the gloom and doom stuff just doesnt always apply. It reminds me of the old exam philosophy of looking askance at Always and Never .....

Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: I get it about the ADT. I’ve been on Lupron for 15 months and have 9 more to go. It has been a slog. I think I’ve had the usual side effects described by almost everyone else. Despite increasing exercise and watching what I eat, I’ve gained 15 pounds. I have a personal trainer, and I think even he is frustrated at how exercises I used to do with ease now cause shortness of breath and the near side of exhaustion. There is a litany of downsides to ADT. All of those are mitigated by a recurrent PSA of 0.1. While I don’t like it, I accept the fact that I was diagnosed with a serious case of oligometastatic Gleason 9 PCa. With RALP, Chemo, 69Gy of radiation and ADT, that PSA has remained constant at 0.1. That’s something to be thankful for.

Posts.Title: Beginning Neoadjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Welcome to the group, and you’re right, most of us don’t want to be there. I commend you for taking responsibility for this journey. There are a lot of resources at hand, and it’s pretty clear you’ve already figured that out. If you haven’t yet read the stickies at the top of our PCa form, do so. There’s a lot of hard work that went into guys who researched (and continue). As you can see from my stats below, I had a RALP at 74. So much for the age deal. My uro and my surgeon were more concerned with my physical condition than my chronological age. Your reasons 1-4 for the surgery look like you’ve done the rational/logical approach, though with a G6, I can see why you’d look at other than surgery first. I think most guys opt first for a cure rather than treatment, but there are so many things to weigh, that it is not a straightforward decision. Incidentally, my biopsy didn’t look all that awful. Once my prostate had its pathology report, it turned out a LOT more serious than expected. Longevity is a crapshoot as it is, but if something serious is going on, get it early before serious turns to tragedy. BTW, as its was explained to me, most surgeons don’t want to deal with prostate removal post radiation because the RT makes it very difficult to do a clean job afterwards.

My uro and my surgeon were more concerned with my physical condition than my chronological age. Your reasons 1-4 for the surgery look like you’ve done the rational/logical approach, though with a G6, I can see why you’d look at other than surgery first. I think most guys opt first for a cure rather than treatment, but there are so many things to weigh, that it is not a straightforward decision. Incidentally, my biopsy didn’t look all that awful. Once my prostate had its pathology report, it turned out a LOT more serious than expected. Longevity is a crapshoot as it is, but if something serious is going on, get it early before serious turns to tragedy. BTW, as its was explained to me, most surgeons don’t want to deal with prostate removal post radiation because the RT makes it very difficult to do a clean job afterwards.

Posts.Title: Hi, I'm a new member

Posts.Content: I’m delighted to see all the multi-variant approaches to treatment. My doctor is part of the “precision treatment” process -- which in essence is tailoring treatment. JH has a lot of stuff going on in this area. As I began treatment there (and I’m in a Phase II clinical trial), I recall specifically asking him why (post RALP) I was starting on chemo rather than the more standard EBRT/ADT route for metastatic PC. His logic seems very sound (I had a couple of lymph nodes that tested positive) “All it takes is a few PC cells wandering around somewhere other than where you’ll be irradiated, the chemo is to give us a shot at them.” While the word “impossible” is pretty harsh, and I’m not an expert in nuclear imaging -- will any scan ever be able to spot a single bad actor cell?

Posts.Title: Can Focal Therapy Replace Radical Therapy for Prostate Cancer? Against Focal Therapy

Posts.Content: Hey Dave, another Hopkins guy here! Your experiences pretty much dovetail with mine. I had a total of 69 Gy. This was around two full months worth -- 1 session a day. I’d already gone through RALP and Chemo before I started radiation. I was started on Lupron coincident with my first Chemo treatment. I’ve been on Lupron now for about 20 months and will have my last injection on 11 March. I have never been overweight in my life. Until I started on Lupron, that is. After the first 6 months, I’d gained 5 pounds. I continued the same level of physical activity (I’ve worked out 2x a week with a personal trainer for 6 years), but it seemed like no matter what I did, I gained weight. At the end of 20 months, I’m 18 pounds overweight. I still have the same focus on fitness I’ve always had -- but I also have the unfortunate 18 pounds which gives me shortness of breath, and physical fatigue I have never had before. I actually had a cardiac consult (with stress EKG) because the shortness of breath scared the hell out of me! So, the good news is my G9 cancer is being held in check (PSA of 0.1 since surgery). . The unhappy news is the side effects of Lupron have been tolerable (except for an inner tube around my middle), the misery of hot flashes, and some minor other outcomes. I look at this stuff and sound whiny. The bigger and more important factor has been extremely positive results in my doctor’s “Kill Cancer” campaign.

Posts.Title: Half Way Through SRT

Posts.Content: So, all of us want to get over the “pad” thing as quickly as possible (I know I did). This may sound weird, but I took the digital kitchen scale (to measure ingredients), and put it in the bathroom. I made a monthly chart with space for each day....and in that space, I wrote in what each pad weighed when I changed it. (The obvious idea was to see the weight decreasing as I went from day to day.) So, this was a real incentive for me to pay attention to strengthening what was left of my pelvic floor muscles. My doc REQUIRED physical therapy prior to and after surgery for strengthening. AND, being able to chart my progress worked -- at least for me. Since I had more treatment post surgery (chemo and radiation), getting dry was essential before I could move on to the next therapy.

Posts.Title: What type of pad to use after catheter removal

Posts.Content: My first brush with ADT was last June. I had the 90 day version of Trelstar. Have had two subsequent injections, but they switched to Lupron. I was told there’s a lot of pressure to go with whatever’s the least expensive (I’m on Medicare and TriCare). I didn’t notice any difference. Side effects are just like everyone else’s on here: weight gain (belly fat), hot flashes multiple times daily, some tiredness. I have really worked on the weight issue with both diet and increased physical exercise (trainer 3x a week), plus three hours of additional cardio. I’m trying hard to avoid cardiovascular and bone issues. I’m on it because I need it, not because I want it. There’s no doubt that ADT has had and is having a clear impact on my life. But, the consequence of NOT doing it is less attractive.

Posts.Title: Update on my other condition...

Posts.Content: Your fianc has a lot going for him. You, primarily. But, he will be the patient and he will be going through the process. While we are all different, I truly believe the more prepared he is, the quicker he’ll be back where a 45 year old ought to be. Since you have had cancer yourself, you have gone through the stages that we all go through. He will as well, and you can obviously facilitate his ability to move through them more easily. I lived for 13 years with a spouse who’d been treated for brain cancer. We had a “new normal” after she had surgery, chemo, and radiation. While I lost her at the end of the 13 years, those years we did have were awesome. She saw our son go from K to graduation from high school. BUT, we did this together. And, that’s what you two will do. You will have a “new normal.” It will be different from pre- prostate cancer. It may well be even better because this experience can and should draw you even closer together. He really does need to get himself prepared for this. You can (and obviously are!) doing the pick and shovel work. But, he’ll be the one dealing with the catheter, incontinence, dribbling, all the possible ED stuff. Most all of the guys on this forum have successfully navigated this disease, so will he, and so will you! Sending good wishes.

AgeInfo.Phrase: he’ll be back where a 45 year old ought to be

Posts.Title: Two days post op

Posts.Content: As you can see from my stats, we have some similarities. Since my doc at Hopkins is a research guy, he advocated (for my case anyway) Docetaxel (4 sessions, 1 every 3 weeks), began ADT coincident with first chemo. 6 weeks post chemo I began RT -- 69 Gy total. Finished RT 23 Nov 17. Now on quarterly ADT. Doing well, but not enjoying the SE of the ADT. The good thing is I can LIVE with them and PSA has remained at .01.

Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer (NEJM)

Posts.Content: Really appreciate your chronological narrative, Fairwind. I’m also in the high-risk category and entered a clinical trial at Johns Hopkins last Spring. If it’s any comfort to you, 6 weeks post RALP I started chemo and ADT. I had four infusions of Docetaxel (taxotere) separated by 3 weeks. Lots of CBC’s, metabolic panels, PSA’s. Also had 69 Gy. The comfort I offer is that the chemo treatments were not all that bad. They prepped me with Dexamethasone the day prior, day of, and day after chemo to reduce nausea. It worked pretty well. My main side effect was tiredness 5 days post chemo (I could set my watch for the regularity). My energy level was somewhat diminished and I did not have the usual appetite. My hair thinned, but I did not lose it. The chemo (as far as I am concerned) was preferable to being on ADT. It surely sounds as if you are receiving terrific care and I’ll be following your progress!

Posts.Title: Three year checkup

Posts.Content: My pre-surgery biopsy showed Gleason 7. My post surgery put me a 9, plus lymph node involvement (2 of 11 nodes positive). I went to Johns Hopkins, (Dr. Jonathan Epstein seems to be regarded as the best -- or one of the best -- pathologists in the business). After reviewing all the slides, Hopkins confirmed the local diagnosis....and I found after the fact that the local pathologist had trained under Epstein. If you have any doubts, by all means get a second opinion. While my pathology didn’t change, the course of treatment I’m undergoing is radically different than I could have expected locally. My doctor says that while he is OK “treating” prostate cancer he’s much more interested in curing it. THAT is a big difference to me. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Is second opinion for pathology need post surgery?

Posts.Content: My doctor recommended Miralax and after a couple of days that did the trick. Everything you’ve described for post-surgery aftereffects sounds amazingly similar. You’re already seeing the urine clear up as you hydrate and pass urine out of your bladder. Remember: your doctor did an anastomosis -- reconnected your urethra to your bladder. They sever the urethra in order to remove your prostate, then sew you back together. (Stark description, but that’s the procedure.) As you can imagine, that stitching causes some clotting and bleeding. It is ABSOLUTELY normal. So is the constipation. It’s an aftereffect of anesthesia and any kind of opiod pain reliever. All this will soon be in your rear view mirror. My major issue was feeling like my insides were coming apart when I coughed!

Posts.Title: Recovering from Robotic Procedure, a question

Posts.Content: Like you, Frank, I decided it was important to do more than just deal with my own situation. My work (like yours) puts me in contact with a lot of people. I have made prostate cancer a part of my work. There’s a lot we can do. I’ve gotten into the Zero Prostate Walk fundraising effort in my community and am planning on being active on the national level this year in lobbying Congress for more money for PCa research. The outreach and meeting others who are also coping with this disease is a great morale lift for me as well. This Forum has had a huge impact on both understanding PCa and dealing with the treatment. Hope you’ll find as much help from the guys on here as I have.

Posts.Title: I went public with my diagnosis

Posts.Content: I’m delighted to see all the multi-variant approaches to treatment. My doctor is part of the “precision treatment” process -- which in essence is tailoring treatment. JH has a lot of stuff going on in this area. As I began treatment there (and I’m in a Phase II clinical trial), I recall specifically asking him why (post RALP) I was starting on chemo rather than the more standard EBRT/ADT route for metastatic PC. His logic seems very sound (I had a couple of lymph nodes that tested positive) “All it takes is a few PC cells wandering around somewhere other than where you’ll be irradiated, the chemo is to give us a shot at them.” While the word “impossible” is pretty harsh, and I’m not an expert in nuclear imaging -- will any scan ever be able to spot a single bad actor cell?

Posts.Title: Can Focal Therapy Replace Radical Therapy for Prostate Cancer? Against Focal Therapy

Posts.Content: Really appreciate your chronological narrative, Fairwind. I’m also in the high-risk category and entered a clinical trial at Johns Hopkins last Spring. If it’s any comfort to you, 6 weeks post RALP I started chemo and ADT. I had four infusions of Docetaxel (taxotere) separated by 3 weeks. Lots of CBC’s, metabolic panels, PSA’s. Also had 69 Gy. The comfort I offer is that the chemo treatments were not all that bad. They prepped me with Dexamethasone the day prior, day of, and day after chemo to reduce nausea. It worked pretty well. My main side effect was tiredness 5 days post chemo (I could set my watch for the regularity). My energy level was somewhat diminished and I did not have the usual appetite. My hair thinned, but I did not lose it. The chemo (as far as I am concerned) was preferable to being on ADT. It surely sounds as if you are receiving terrific care and I’ll be following your progress!

Posts.Title: Fairwind's Journey

Posts.Content: I’ve been in treatment at Johns Hopkins since I had the RALP. I head up there every 90 days (I’m in a clinical trial). JH does not routinely use the ultra sensitive PSA, at least they haven’t in my case. I asked my Doctor (Ken Pienta) about it and he said, “we’re fine with the standard PSA.” I completely and totally trust his judgment, but I’m also convinced we’re dealing with both art and science in treating PCa. If there’s going to be BCR, I’m confident he’ll be up to the challenge that may present.

Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: From your stats, I’m glad to see you’re moving quickly for both the ADT and the radiation. I had a total of 69gy, finished right before Thanksgiving. The ADT began before the radiation as it tends to provide some additional benefit in the radiation process. Except for the hot flashes (which are annoying) my only issue with ADT has been weight gain. I’ve gained about 12 pounds in the last year, despite being very active. I just do not seem to burn off calories. You clearly have a scheduling challenge ahead of you. You have to decide how you set the priority to complete treatment.

Posts.Content: Like you, Frank, I decided it was important to do more than just deal with my own situation. My work (like yours) puts me in contact with a lot of people. I have made prostate cancer a part of my work. There’s a lot we can do. I’ve gotten into the Zero Prostate Walk fundraising effort in my community and am planning on being active on the national level this year in lobbying Congress for more money for PCa research. The outreach and meeting others who are also coping with this disease is a great morale lift for me as well. This Forum has had a huge impact on both understanding PCa and dealing with the treatment. Hope you’ll find as much help from the guys on here as I have.

Posts.Content: I agree with my esteemed colleague HighlanderCFH. I’m being treated at Hopkins. Epstein is (without much argument), the best pathologist in the US, and perhaps the world, when it comes to accuracy of prostate diagnosis. The pathologist who first did my diagnosis was not Epstein. The second was Epstein. Both of the pathology reports were virtually identical. I then found out that the first pathologist had trained under Epstein. My MD at Hopkins and I had a laugh about this.

Posts.Title: What Do You Do When Your 2nd Opinion Is Different From Your First

Posts.Content: HI Trex, As youve already experienced, there is a warm welcome when you become one of us. While none of us want to be here, there is a lot of great info provided, completely non-judgmental support, and a willingness to answer any question -- even if it seems small and unimportant. im also in the high risk category (higher than you, though I really dont much want to compete for that honor. The info youll be given from your medical team will kind of dribble out (bad metaphor), you may find this tough and anxiety inducing. The guys who post on here can be very helpful by translating stuff into understandable points as you get further on into the process. While nobody is a urologic surgeon, RO, or oncologist, there is a lot of knowledge that will give you deeper understanding of whats going on. Ive been on here for just short of two years. Really have appreciated the support, and I know you will as well.

Posts.Content: Very good summary of how to move forward. I’ve had quite a few phone calls with other guys who are facing PCa, and some mutual sharing most definitely helps. But, in the still of the night I sometimes find myself asking the tough question about progression and survival. After getting a G9 pathology report, I chose to head to Hopkins for treatment (“serious disease, serious treatment”). I’m doing everything I can to stay positive and be healthy....despite having the stone of ADT around my neck. My friends and family have all been awesome. Thanksgiving will be special again this year.

Posts.Title: Choose life over fear

Posts.Content: This week was my quarterly check-up at Johns Hopkins. In order to remain compliant with my clinical trial they run a CBC, Metabolic Panel, Testosterone AND (of course), the PSA every 90 days. I also get the wonderful Lupron Injection. I had blood drawn on the 17th, and all the numbers are now in: all looking good, and the PSA held at 0.1. Ive avoided thinking about ADT, and just deal with it. Ive now had 7 injections and one more to go. This makes for a great start to the holiday season! Just back from a month down under. Two weeks in Australia and two weeks in New Zealand. VERY good for my morale. Merry Christmas to all of you.

Posts.Title: Still Exhaling

Posts.Content: I can only share my experience, but for me, I really wanted my doctor(s) to be aggressive in knocking down any remaining cancer post-RALP. My PSA post surgery was the same as yours, and all of my medical team agreed that SRT was definitely in order. (And ADT -- but my PCa was more advanced than yours.) I think there’s a general trend to try and “clean-up” any remaining activity that escaped the surgeon’s knife. You can surely opt for a second opinion, but my uninformed guess is that you’re probably getting good advice given your pathology stats.

Posts.Content: I keep up with the postings here pretty regularly, and when I reflect back to the beginning of this journey (unwanted though it may be), I’m struck by how much I’ve learned about the disease in the last 22 months. There surely is value in better understanding the complexity and enormous variability within the PCa framework. Pat Walsh’s book (which I first heard about here), gave me a good foundation and made me a LOT more comfortable when I started this journey two years ago. I’m realizing more and more about the impact this brotherhood has. Twice this year my doc at Hopkins has asked me if I’d be willing to talk to a couple of his new patients about my journey. Of course I said, yes. These two guys were eligible for a clinical trial, but were nervous about it. After sharing my clinical trial experiences I suggested both of them check out this great forum. While I realize different people have different needs for information, my preference is for as much data as I can get. You folks really have helped with timely info. So, thanks!

Age.Phrase: of a glioblastoma at age 62   and some other hereditary nastiness

DoctorRecommended.Sample: As others have suggested, it would be a very good thing if the urologist (and a urologic oncologist) sat down with the cardiologist and reviewed specifics. As already pointed out, there are clear options besides surgery (Gleason 7 notwithstanding), and having a second opinion and a multidisciplinary team of doctors communicating, I think this is a good plan of attack!...My doctor recommended Miralax and after a couple of days that did the trick. Everything youve described for post-surgery aftereffects sounds amazingly similar....
